title: isco-crosswalks
text: Eurostat, CEDEFOP, EU agencies looking using ESCO classification link job–worker characteristics like skill importance level ratings European jobs. O*NET reliable source occupational data European labour market strong theoretical empirical basis similarities European US economic systems. Drawing O*NET necessitates mapping one classification another since O*NET database classifies jobs differently EU. accomplished via “concordance” (also known “crosswalk” “correspondence table”). propose publicly accessible software methodologically transparent concordances, constructing R-package hope greatly reduce expenses time required perform approximate mapping two categorization systems. ESCO began evaluating several options tying skills professions EU. introduction Skills Competencies Taxonomy, knowledge descriptors, provides consistent nomenclature enhances communication occupational information EU, first stage process. One obvious source consider evaluate various options utilize ESCO Taxonomy US O*NET system. Indeed, assess skills competencies different segments EU labour market, various governmental non-governmental organizations EU built concordances US System Occupational Classification (SOC) ESCO. problem clear one--one mapping EU ESCO US SOC utilized O*NET jobs. result, many concordances concentrated solely occupations clear one--one correspondences. Furthermore, concordances frequently proprietary, little information explanation created, making inaccessible others limiting critique approach adopted. Understanding variations jobs organized US EU necessary realize necessity granular concordance. SOC ESCO similar goals, significant distinctions organization information included occupational profiles. US SOC 867 6-digit classifications statistics reporting (e.g., number people employed average wage). EU ESCO, hand, employs ISCO 4-digit categorization, 436 unit groups, adds extra layer information approximately 3000 occupational distinctions. systems group occupations according four-level hierarchy, ESCO adding extra degree detail.

title: isco-crosswalks
text: build algorithm conducts approximate matching ISCO SOC classifications using concordances provided Institute Structural Research Faculty Economics, University Warsaw. crosswalks offer complete step--step mapping O*NET data ISCO88 ISCO-08 coding using expanded version SOC-00 SOC-10 coding (used European data, including EU LFS). propose mapping method based aforementioned research converts measurements smallest possible unit target taxonomy, performs aggregation/estimate appropriate degree detail. case raw-count data sum breakdown group used, else mean value.

title: isco-crosswalks
text: basic example shows translate CEDEFOPs “Importance foundation skills” indicator given ISCO(2008) SOC(2010) classification: details visit CEDEFOPs skills intelligence tool percentage jobs foundation skills (literacy, numeracy, ICT, foreign languages) highly crucial work shown indicator. based findings Cedefop’s European survey skills jobs. Skills Foundation Indicator exposed also iscoCrosswalks example data-set. consists three variables Occupations Skill Value perform transformation, ’ve added third column preferredLabel ISCO taxonomy. R terminal, type isco access desired labels. Manual entry preferred labels suggested small data. See also R package labourR automating occupations coding, case big data-sets. Inspecting indicator, translate indicator SOC classification, iscoCrosswalks two mandatory column names. Namely, job value standing preferred labels taxonomy value indicator respectively. Thus, rename preferredLabel job, Value value. isco_soc_crosswalk() function can translate values desired taxonomy. parameter brkd_cols accepts vector indicates columns used grouping. Also, since composite score set indicator = TRUE use mean value. Instead, raw counts given set indicator = FALSE aggregate units hierarchy. following table visualize top 6 occupations Skill, projected indicator SOC taxonomy. reverse process required, use soc_isco_crosswalk() function. preffered labels taxonomy can inspected included dataset soc_groups.
code: library(iscoCrosswalks) kable(foundation_skills[seq(1 , nrow(foundation_skills), by = 5), ]) data.table::setnames(foundation_skills,                      c("preferredLabel", "Value"),                      c("job", "value")) soc_foundation_skills <- isco_soc_crosswalk(foundation_skills,                                             brkd_cols = "Skill",                                             isco_lvl = 1,                                             soc_lvl = "soc_1",                                             indicator = TRUE) soc_foundation_skills[, Occupations := gsub(" Occupations", "", soc_label)] soc_foundation_skills[, Skill := gsub(" skills", "", Skill)] dat <- soc_foundation_skills[order(Skill, -value)][, head(.SD, 6), by = "Skill"] kable(dat)

title: Get ISCO code — get_isco_code
code: library(iscoCrosswalks) # add mandatory column dat <- foundation_skills[, .(job = preferredLabel, Skill, Value)] res <- get_isco_code(dat, lvl = 1) head(res[, .(code, Skill, Value)]) #>    code                   Skill Value #> 1:    4 Foreign language skills  8.40 #> 2:    4                     ICT 80.56 #> 3:    4                Literacy 51.51 #> 4:    4                Numeracy 26.30 #> 5:    7 Foreign language skills  4.59 #> 6:    7                     ICT 34.80

title: ISCO to SOC crosswalk — isco_soc_crosswalk
text: 2010 Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) International Standard Classification Occupations (ISCO-08) compared. make crosswalk straightforward hence useful, notion parsimony applied. means task completed SOC may appear numerous ISCOs (vice versa), match instances just coincidental adds unneeded complexity. function allows mapping data top 3 ISCO levels 4 SOC groups.

title: SOC to ISCO crosswalk — soc_isco_crosswalk
text: 2010 Standard Occupational Classification (SOC) International Standard Classification Occupations (ISCO-08) compared. make crosswalk straightforward hence useful, notion parsimony applied. means task completed SOC may appear numerous ISCOs (vice versa), match instances just coincidental adds unneeded complexity. function allows mapping data 4 SOC groups 4 ISCO levels.

title: SOC to ISCO crosswalk — soc_isco_crosswalk
code: soc_isco_crosswalk(   data,   soc_lvl,   isco_lvl,   brkd_cols = NULL,   indicator = FALSE )

title: SOC to ISCO crosswalk — soc_isco_crosswalk
text: data, data.table mandatory columns job value soc_lvl, character taking values soc_1 soc_4 isco_lvl, numeric 1 4 brkd_cols, character vector col names stratification variables indicator, Boolean indicating data describe indicator. TRUE mean value computed, otherwise sum breakdown group.

text: Hardy W, Keister R, Lewandowski P (2018). “Educational upgrading, structural change task composition jobs Europe.” Economics Transition, 26(2), 201--231.

title: SOC to ISCO crosswalk — soc_isco_crosswalk
code: library(iscoCrosswalks) library(data.table) #from soc_3 group to ISCO level 1 occupations path <- system.file("extdata", "soc_3_brkdwn_example.csv",                     package = "iscoCrosswalks") dat <- fread(path) soc_isco_crosswalk(dat,                    soc_lvl = "soc_3",                    isco_lvl = 1,                    brkd_cols = "gender") #>     isco08                          preferredLabel gender     value #>  1:      5               Service and sales workers   Male 82.142857 #>  2:      5               Service and sales workers Female 52.457143 #>  3:      3 Technicians and associate professionals   Male 27.600000 #>  4:      3 Technicians and associate professionals Female 17.300000 #>  5:      2                           Professionals   Male  8.400000 #>  6:      1                                Managers   Male  6.857143 #>  7:      4                Clerical support workers   Male  6.000000 #>  8:      2                           Professionals Female  6.000000 #>  9:      1                                Managers Female  5.142857 #> 10:      4                Clerical support workers Female  3.100000
